question1.question:
A sales manager at Ursa Major Solar wants a team of sales reps to know how many open opportunities they have at any given time.
How should an administrator configure a report for each sales rep to see their own open opportunities?
question1.option1text: Create a reporting snapshot grouped by sales rep.
question1.option1textexplanation: Incorrect. This does not show a sales rep just their own open opportunities.
question1.option2text: Create a report with a cross filter by My Opportunities.
question1.option2textexplanation: Incorrect. Cross filters are used in reports to filter for cross object fields.
question1.option3text: Create a report filtered by My Opportunities.
question1.option3textexplanation: Correct. This report shows a sales rep their own open opportunities.
question1.option4text: Create a report schedule for each sales rep.
question1.option4textexplanation: Incorrect. A schedule doesn’t create a report that allows each sales rep to see their own open opportunities.

question2.accessibility: Question 2. This question has 5 possible answer(s) to chose from. The question has 3 correct answer(s).
question2.question: Which three report charts show how many leads are in the marketing pipeline based on lead status and what percent each lead status represents? (Choose three answers.)
question2.option1textexplanation: Incorrect. A grouped bar chart shows siloed, individual lead information.
question2.option2textexplanation: Correct. A pie chart shows the number of leads and the percentage of leads as part of the whole.
question2.option3textexplanation: Correct. A donut chart shows the number of leads and the percentage of leads as part of the whole.
question2.option4textexplanation: Incorrect. A line chart does not show a percentage of leads relative to the whole.
question2.option5textexplanation: Correct. A funnel chart shows the number of leads and the percentage of leads as part of the whole.

question3.accessibility: Question 3. This question has 4 possible answer(s) to chose from. The question has 2 correct answer(s).
question3.question:
A finance user with the View All Data permission enabled sees no opportunities when opening a sales pipeline report. However, a sales rep sees opportunities as expected. Opportunities should be visible to only those with permission.
Which two actions should the administrator perform to ensure that the finance user sees opportunities in the pipeline report? (Choose two answers.)
question3.option1text: Select Save Hierarchy Level on the pipeline report.
question3.option1textexplanation: Correct. The Save Hierarchy Level checkbox being selected ensures that the hierarchy level that was used when creating a report stays intact. So if the finance user had permission to see reports originally, the same applies when any subsequent report is created.
question3.option2text: Create a new report formula on the pipeline report.
question3.option2textexplanation: Incorrect: Creating a formula does not change which opportunities are visible.
question3.option3text: Update the report filter to show all opportunities.
question3.option3textexplanation: Correct. Using a filter to show all opportunities allows users with the View All Data permission enabled to see all of the opportunities on the report.
question3.option4text: Change the org-wide opportunity sharing default to Public Read.
question3.option4textexplanation: Incorrect. This would allow everyone in the organization to see opportunities.

question4.accessibility: Question 4. This question has 4 possible answer(s) to chose from. The question has 1 correct answer(s).
question4.question: What should an administrator configure to provide each sales rep a dashboard that shows their current Opportunity pipeline?
question4.option1text: Set a dashboard filter to the current user.
question4.option1textexplanation: Incorrect. Setting the dashboard filter to the current user would only show opportunities for that user, not the user running the dashboard.
question4.option2text: Create a dashboard folder for each user.
question4.option2textexplanation: Incorrect. Creating a dashboard folder for each user would not filter the dashboard for users. A dashboard folder is for storing dashboards, limiting visibility to the dashboards in the folder.
question4.option3text: Filter the dashboard with a dynamic view set to the VP of sales.
question4.option3textexplanation:
Incorrect. Dynamic dashboards are limited. The View Dashboard As options are:
Me
Another person
Dashboard viewer
question4.option4text: Set the dashboard running user to "the dashboard viewer.“
question4.option4textexplanation: Correct. This ensures that the dashboard shows data relevant to only the user viewing it.

question5.question:
A sales user wants to add components to their dashboard.
What is the maximum number of components that can be added to a single dashboard?
question5.option1textexplanation: Incorrect. Each dashboard can have up to 20 components. Each report can have up to 3 cross filters.
question5.option2textexplanation: Incorrect. Each dashboard can have up to 20 components.
question5.option3textexplanation: Correct. Each dashboard can have up to 20 components.
question5.option4textexplanation: Incorrect. Each dashboard can have up to 20 components. A dashboard filter can have up to 50 values.

question6.accessibility: Question 6. This question has 4 possible answer(s) to chose from. The question has 1 correct answer(s).
question6.question: What should the system administrator do when users are unable to find a custom report type?
question6.option1text: Make sure the new report type is deployed.
question6.option1textexplanation: Correct. Users are not able to access a custom report type if it hasn’t been deployed.
question6.option2text: Make sure the user profile includes the report type.
question6.option2textexplanation: Incorrect. Access to objects is controlled by profiles not based on report type.
question6.option3text: Add the new report type to the related objects.
question6.option3textexplanation: Incorrect. Report types are created for the object that is reported on.
question6.option4text: Add a button for the new report type to the Report Builder.
question6.option4textexplanation: Incorrect. Report types are part of the Report Builder when deployed.

question7.question:
Ursa Major Solar uses a private data access model. Product managers and sales representatives are in different branches of the role hierarchy.
What should an administrator do to ensure that product managers can report on opportunities in their product line?
question7.option1text: Create a sharing rule based on criteria.
question7.option1textexplanation: Correct. Criteria-based sharing rules determine what records to share based on field values other than ownership.
question7.option2text: Save all opportunity reports in a public folder.
question7.option2textexplanation: Incorrect. Saving reports in a public folder will give access to everyone.
question7.option3text: Move all product managers to a role below the sales representatives.
question7.option3textexplanation: Incorrect. If product managers are in a role below sales representatives, they will not be able to see the reports. Product managers would have to be in a role above the sales representatives according to the role hierarchy.
question7.option4text: Create a new role for product managers and sales representatives.
question7.option4textexplanation: Incorrect. Creating a new role would further separate the role hierarchy. The product managers and sales representatives would not need to be combined or branched off.
